physDesc.p: This letter consists of two typed pages on carbon paper. In the upper lefthand corner is the address header. The upper righthand side contains a dateline. On the second page, there is a header above the dateline (Mr. Aldington - 2)

div.p: As you probably know by this time, Miss Cutting of the “North American Review” has taken your “Eumenides,” I asked her to write to you about it direct. Your other poems I have not yet been able to do anything about, as I have not been to New York since I received them. I will, however, attend to them as soon as possible. I do not think there is the slightest doubt that I shall be able to place some of them; I hope not, anyway. Of course the Summer is a slow time, for these things go better if I see the editors personally, and I do not go to New York in the Summer.

Hilda writes me that she will arrive in New York about the 8th of September, and I rather think I shall go on to meet the steamer and see her then. I am writing to her mother to see if she is going to meet the steamer, and it occurs to me that they be anxious to get rid of Winifred Ellerman for a little while. They may want to see each other without her, and I have written Hilda that if my health holds out, as I trust it will, I shall be very glad to have Winifred here for a little while.

This is hardly a letter to you in answer to your splendid one of the 17th of June, because I am just rushing out to Chicago to give a couple of lectures before the Summer School of the University of Chicago, and I have no time to do more than send this line now.

I like your “Nightingale” immensely, and also your “Night Fancies,” the others perhaps not quite so much. I will write you about them at length, and also do more jusice to your splendid letter, when I get back from Chicago next week. If only this hernia will let me, and they do not insist on cutting me up just at that time, I shall certainly come over to
England next Spring. I feel I must get there.

Hilda's book has arrived and I am going to try and place it. I am glad the “Dial” has paid you promptly. They are good at paying. Whether they will pay you the odd $30.00 or not of course I do not know; they said they would look it up. I have a theory that Brown is in difficulties. He sent out a man to see me yesterday, but he would not state his business to my secretary and I could not see him. I am glad he has paid you something, anyway.

Let me hastily say that I did not mean that all French criticism was “too long, too meticulous, and too dull in the way of expressing itself.” I meant merely that of many of the younger men, not, of course, of the superb older critics. There is nothing like them. I have been slamming the last Georgian Anthology in the “Dial,” which I suppose spoils me for England. Don't, for Heaven's sake, imagine that American poetry is going the way of the kind they publish in the “Dial.” Erstline Cummings is punk of the punkest, and Schofield Thayer (the “Dial” editor) has fallen for him hard.

I see I am writing a letter after all, but I cannot, I must not. I have a lot of nasty things to get off before I go, and I am going to stop right now - bang! I will write you a decent letter when I get home.

postscript.p: Miss Lowell was obliged to leave before this letter could be signed.
